title: Original Stack Trace is Not Defined (promievent.js)

body:
This line strikes me as problematic:

```javascript
        return instance.getBalanceInEth.call(account)                          // BREAKS HERE
```

Trouble is: `instance.getBalanceInEth` is a function, so when you do `instance.getBalanceInEth.call`, you're invoking [Function.prototype.call](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function/call). The error you're seeing is because `account` is passed as the first argument, thus binding `this` to `account` instead `instance.getBalanceInEth`.

Try doing `instance.getBalanceInEth(account)` instead.

@gnidan That's not what should happen?  If `getBalanceInEth` is a method of the contract instance, then `instance.getBalanceInEth.call(account)` should do it as a call; Truffle Contract provides that.  Of course, if `getBalanceInEth` is a `view` or `pure` function, then it will call by default, but Truffle Contract provides `call` for all contract methods; `Function.prototype.call` should not get invoked.
@karthedew Could you clarify what the Solidity code you were using is?  You make it sound like you were using a box; could you clarify which one?
OK, I think I've identified the problem, and have put up a PR to fix it.  We'll see if this does indeed resolve it.

@haltman-at , I implemented your changes directly in my local @truffle/contract package. Changes fixed the current issue.

Unfortunately this has exposed another challenge...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35015336/88068798-8a230200-cb25-11ea-8ab7-92952a1f5f04.png)


It appears as though the txHash is not getting set when you use the call() method ( in this case, [ ``` return instance.getBalanceInEth.call() ```]). 

The transaction hash looks like it should be set in "Execute.js" on line 544. The method above does not actually make it to this part of the code, so ```this.txHash``` never gets set in the promievent object.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35015336/88069101-e554f480-cb25-11ea-8f73-aec34490a2ff.png)


I plan to investigate further, but I am not sure if this should be written up in a new Issue? 

Hopefully there is an easy solution to this.

Indeed, `txHash` will not be set if you used call.  But that does not seem to be the problem here, nor do I see any reason it would cause a problem.  Rather, from your error message, it seems to be complaining that `this` is undefined!

I'm not sure what to do about that.  That said, since you seem to be willing to twiddle the code yourself, here's something you could try (and if this works then we can merge it).  On line 74, does anything change if you replace
```
  this.reject = rejectHijacker;
```
with
```
  this.reject = rejectHijacker.bind(this);
```

That's the best thing I can think of at the moment.  But I'll try a more detailed reproduction myself later and try to see what's going on.

Thanks for the report!

It looks like that was the issue. binding ```this``` to ```rejectHijacker;``` worked. 

Just got a chain of problems here though. 

I don't think this is necessarily a problem with the code? It could be how I have Ganache setup? Though I am able to pull the Ganache accounts with MetaMask and web3.

I feel like ```rpcReturn``` should be known when the Ganache provider (localhost:7545 on my machine) is set to the ContractABI?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35015336/88123143-1e6d8300-cb7f-11ea-8cc6-e0a9bcd95e6e.png)

Anyways, maybe this issue can be closed as the fixes seem to have fixed my original problem....

OK, thanks for checking that!  I've put up a PR to fix the second problem.

But that does leave us with the third one.  That one I'm confused about; `rpcReturn` shouldn't be undefined.  I'm going to have to try reproducing your problem myself and see what might be causing that.

(To be clear -- what these problems all have in common is that they're all problems in our code used for producing stacktraces in Truffle Test.  Just to be clear, that is the context this is all occurring in, right?  You're not getting these problems outside of Truffle Test, and not if you don't explicitly ask for stacktraces, right?  If you're getting these problems outside of Truffle Test, or even when you don't ask for stacktraces, then something is very wrong...)

**Edit**: Actually that's not quite right -- it makes some sense to me that the previous two could have occurred without that, since thinking about it that code will actually run regardless.  But this third one is in code that should only run if you're getting stacktraces.  Could you confirm that that's what you're doing?  (Or confirm that that's not what you're doing, in which case something has gone very wrong somewhere?)

I am confused about this statement, though:

>  the Ganache provider (localhost:7545 on my machine) is set to the ContractABI

Could you explain what you mean by that?  I'm afraid I don't understand.

Anyway I'll try reproducing this and see if I can get that third problem to pop up.  Thanks for the report!
I think this issue may be resolved in Truffle 5.1.36. If you upgrade, does your problem persist?
Well, the initial two issues should be fixed in 5.1.36; I didn't yet get to this third issue being discussed.

@karthedew I see, weird!  So, to explain a bit more -- I wrote some functionality that allows contracts to generate stacktraces for reverted transactions when the contract's methods are invoked from Truffle Test.  The line about `rpcReturn` is part of that functionality.  I'm confused as to why it's being hit here, as from what you're saying, this is not occurring inside Truffle Test.

So, yeah, going to have to sit down and try to reproduce this.  Not very familiar with front-end stuff but I'll see first if I can reproduce it outside of that context; otherwise I guess I'll have to try to figure out how Angular works...
Thanks for your help @haltman-at! Didn't get a chance to look further into it last weekend. Will have some time this week though.

Alternatively, @karthedew, could you provide more detailed instructions regarding the setup here?  As someone who doesn't know Angular, it's a bit underspecified.  (Alternatively, do you have a reproduction repo I could just check out?)

Like, create an Angular project, OK; unbox Metacoin, compile and deploy, OK; but I don't understand where to put the rest of the code that you list (what file does it go in?) in order to make it part of the Angular project, nor how to then invoke it.  Could you fill in the gaps?  Thank you!

After your verification that the Truffle contract code is working correctly with no rpcRetrun issues, I'm wondering of there is a communication restriction between Angular and Ganache server through RPC requests. 

I thought maybe it was related to setting up CORS when you are running both a Frontend server and Backend server on the same machine, but in different ports. Usually this is setup on the backend side of things. Alternatively, you can also setup a Proxy configuration file (see, [article]( https://www.positronx.io/handle-cors-in-angular-with-proxy-configuration/#:~:text=Enable%20CORS%20with%20Proxy%20Configuration%20Settings%20in%20Angular.&text=To%20enable%20CORS%20via%20proxy,the%20deliberate%20use%20of%20SSL.)).

I tried this out, but unfortunately with no progress. 

Did a little more research and then came across [this issue](https://github.com/trufflesuite/ganache/issues/359). So it seems that RPC capabilities were already added to Ganache.

@karthedew Thanks!  I missed where you posted that repo originally.  Unfortunately I can't seem to get it working?  I downloaded it like you suggested, went into `Frontend/web3front`, upgraded the `@truffle/contract` version and ran `npm install`; and then tried just running `npm start` like you suggested.  However, when I pointed my browser to `http://localhost:4200/`, what I got was an error page (titled `Error`) with just the message `Cannot GET /`.

Looking at the terminal window where I ran `npm start`, I see a lot of "Can't resolve module" errors, which is strange, because I ran `npm install`.  Following that, I see a large number of `ENOENT` errors coming from something trying to find certain directories in my home directory -- namely, `~/external`, `~/externhome`, `~/externwinhome`, `~/tbhome`, and `~/winhome`.  Of course I don't have any of these directories.

So, something seems to be missing here.  Are there additional steps I should take here to get this project running?  Thank you!

(As for the rest... again, to my mind, the real question is why the function where this error occurs is being called at all.  If it's not in the context of `truffle test`, that function shouldn't even be called...)

Also tried this again after actually installing the peer dependencies this time (sort of).  (I say sort of because there was actually no way for me to satisfy all the peer dependencies?  Because some things required `@angular/compiler` v9, and some things required `@angular/compiler` v10; I ended up going with v9 as only `@angular/compiler-cli` required v10, whereas various things required v9?)

This led to the same result in the browser, but a rather different error in the terminal:

```
ERROR in TypeError: Cannot read property 'start' of undefined
    at Object.addParseSpanInfo (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/diagnostics.js:56:32)
    at AstTranslator.visitPropertyRead (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:203:27)
    at PropertyRead.visit (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:7462:28)
    at AstTranslator.translate (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:74:24)
    at /home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:118:124
    at Array.reduce (<anonymous>)
    at AstTranslator.visitInterpolation (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:118:36)
    at Interpolation.visit (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:7590:28)
    at AstTranslator.translate (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:74:24)
    at Object.astToTypescript (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/expression.js:51:27)
    at TcbExpressionTranslator.translate (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:1213:33)
    at tcbExpression (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:1201:27)
    at TcbTextInterpolationOp.execute (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:317:24)
    at Scope.executeOp (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:976:26)
    at Scope.render (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:889:22)
    at Object.generateTypeCheckBlock (/home/sniffnoy/truffle/AngularTruffleExample/Frontend/web3front/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/typecheck/src/type_check_block.js:57:37)
```

So, uh, I still haven't managed to get this working well enough to replicate the issue.  I guess I can retry it with v10...?  Or is there some way to make all the dependencies happy...?
Hm, no, that gets me back to the same problem I had before, more or less.  So, uh, @karthedew, I can't figure out how to get this project working?

@haltman-at hmm, that's interesting. I removed all global packages in npm so I'd have a clean slate. Pulled down the project from GitHub and did "npm install" then ran "npm start". This worked for me, so I'm not sure what's going on here. 

I did see that I had the ```pacakge-lock.json``` file still in the repo. Maybe try deleting that file and the ```node_modules``` and try the ```npm install``` again. 

One thing to note is that Angular does not mix versions. So whatever packages you have for Angular need to all be the exact same versions. I'm not sure why you were seeing dependencies for version 10? The ```package.json``` file was all v9.0.7.

I'm wondering if trying a different version of Angular would fix this problem. I'll try that and see what happens.
@haltman-at Just thought you could also try running ```ng update --all``` to get the latest version of all packages. This might also help fix the issue.
Aha, indeed, `ng update --all` seems to have finally gotten it working, thanks! :)  Now let's see about reproducing this error...

Hm, so I'm running into a different problem trying to test this: As best I can tell, my browser is blocking all the requests made to the Ganache instance due to them not passing same-origin policy / CORS.  So basically nothing's working.  Will have to see if I can find a way around this.

Edit: Nevermind, this was not the actual problem, disregard this.

OK, finally got this up and running with Angular, and I'm afraid I still can't reproduce this problem.  I'm getting the account balance printed out on the console just fine.  (It prints out the BN object, mind you, because I didn't add anything to convert it away from a BN, but I am getting the BN, not an error.)

So I ended up running the same ```ng update --all```, and this did the trick. There must've been some Angular packages that weren't coordinating together, is my bet? Angular requires everything to be the same version, though it's sometimes easy to install different versions between different Angular packages. 

Thanks so much for all your help! I think we can close this issue.
Hm, weird.  No idea.  Guess I'll close this!  Thanks for all the help with reproducing this.
